dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A battered old rescue tug churns north through broken pac A MAN stands in the prow staring at the world of ice. A w He signals up to CAPTAIN. The boat slows to a halt. The m shoulders a small pack. He climbs over onto a ladder and onto the frozen edge of the pack ice. He turns his back o boat and starts walking toward the distant shore. The CAPTAIN stares at the receding figure, expressionless pushes the throttle forward and the boat moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small in the frame the man trudges resolute toward nothin wind starting to whip up. He climbs through the maze of ice and rock to reach the p the glacier. He stops and shrugs off the pack, roots arou takes something out, we can't see what. He unzips the par puts the object in his waist and zips up and sets off aga Incomprehensibly he leaves the pack behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man has been walking a long time. He stops and looks Ice. Mountains behind. The green-black of the sea out in Not a human sign, no life at all. Except... AN ARCTIC FOX, buried almost invisible, watching. The man looks up at THE AURORA BOREALIS - eerie dancing s green and purple flowing across the sky. Tighter on THE MAN’S FACE: looking up..hollowed out, haun

dialogues.speaker: MEMORY _FLASH
dialogues.text: A banshee shriek of sound. An image streaked liked a came on a slow shutter. A WOMAN’S BODY on the ground, FLAMES.. probably can't make it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MAN’S EYES: wide open. Anguish. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca He takes off the parka and throws it away from him and i by the wind. He falls to his knees, much too exposed now. stares forward at nothing, gathering his will. And now we see the GUN in his waistband. His hand takes i points it down and into the snow but he stares ahead. His thumb PULLS THE HAMMER BACK and the heartbeat starts From behind and to the side a bit: THE DULL PULSE OF A GR GLOW IN THE BASE OF HIS SKULL, beneath the edge of his ca EYES: flaring wide snapping from blue to DEEP GLOWING GRE From behind him again: the hand with the gun JERKS UP - THE FOX in the snow: a FLASH OF GREEN LIGHT on the white a muffled report of a GUNSHOT and the fox is gone... From a distance: the man, hard to make out the figure fro far away, hard to get a sense of scale.. still on the kne bent, falling forward now but HIS ARM SHOOTS OUT TO CATCH THE ARM: close on the forearm as it hits the snow, hand outstretched. HUGE. MUSCLED. GREEN. A clicking sound.metal on teeth..the hand rises toward th of frame and the clicking stops. The hand lowers, open. A MASSIVE FLAT PALM WITH A BULLET IN IT. Smashed completely A long beat with nothing but cold wind.

dialogues.text: Over many hours, Banner works. Methodically and painstaki extracting tiny amounts of juice from his precious flower it carefully with chemicals from self-labeled bottles and it all in an assortment of glasses doubling as homemade t tubes; cooking it down over a small gas flame. Referring NOTES on his computer. Finally, all seems ready...a final step. He PRICKS HIS OWN FINGER...so carefully placing ONE DROP BLOOD on a glass slide. He slides it under the microscope looks at it: C.U. - BANNER’S BLOOD: red blood cells fringed with a sub GLOWING GREEN ENERGY. Like residual radiation. He takes the slide back out. Takes a breath. This is it. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca In a dropper, he extracts some of the PURPLISH LIQUID he slowly refining from the very small amount in the glass. Carefully he brings it over the blood sample... and squee TWO THREE drops onto the blood. He places the slide under the SCOPE and looks again: C.U. - BLOOD: The Purple liquid seems to be literally boi away around the cells. Frying. No change. The GREEN TINGE still there. BANNER pulls back from the scope and puts his forehead ag heel of his hands. He had let himself hope and now he is devastated. BANNER’S SCREEN: Green: “No mitigation.” Blue: “None? Your tissue exposure must be relatively high Green: “Very high. Blue: “Try a higher concentration. Slightly. 100 parts pe = lethal toxicity.” BANNER leans back and looks at: HIS WILTED FLOWERS. He ha them for all they have. Green: “Impossible at present. Supply is limited.” Blue: “Not here. We’re making pure synthetic by the gallo (pause) “Why are we doing this backwards? Chasing flowers in the silly. Send me a blood sample.” Green: “Not prudent.” Blue: “Living with Gamma poisoning not prudent. Most peop alive long enough to be helped. Intrigued by your case.” Green: “Not safe for either of us.” Blue: “You need help. Gamma not something to mess with.”

His terrif drowned by... A ROAR OF RAGE unlike anything. PRIMAL. Not human. ROSS and CABOT: the sound ripping into their earphones “W the...?” THE DARK OF THE FACTORY: The sound of bone cracking and T LEADER's TERRIFIED SCREAM OF PAIN and then... ...HE FLIES OUT OF THE DARK, from a height of 14 feet and as he goes... thrown literally across the factory like a ball, clipping through shafts of light and hitting the fa head first so hard that you hope he didn't survive. The ROAR fading... A STRANGE BEAT OF SILENCE, as each fac grasp the IMPOSSIBLE.

TEAM 1 POV: THE TOUGHS explode toward us out of dark, pan straight at camera the last of them rising from the Dart- friend, a step behind and too slow for THE HUGE ARM THAT OF THE DARK TO GRAB HIM AND YANK HIM BACK. BLONSKY: as the TOUGHS sprint past him in the dark, not e noticing him. HE SAW THAT ARM. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  25. Dropped like a rag-doll. A THE SHAPE starts to move...

We can see the tops of huge arr shaking in the light. Sounds of metal wrenching and huge percussive smashes. And somewhere in all the chaos a butt hit and all the belts and bottles start to move. Adding t confusion and sound.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t let him out of the building! Put all your trangs in him! Every one you've got! Do it now!! TEAM 2: Advancing forward slightly on the THING IN THE DA A Shadow moving among the metal and Team 2 opens up. THWWP. THWWP. THWWP. Darts zipping into the dark. A PATCH OF LIGHT on the concrete floor and the darts fall Bent at right angles like they've hit a concrete wall. THE SHADOW SPINS AND COMES AT THEM.

dialogues.speaker: TEAM 2 NIGHT VISION
dialogues.text: TEAM 2: whipping up machine guns...

Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  26. TEAM 3's POV: In the black, they see the muzzle flashes o MP5's open up from Team 2's position, an incredible clatt weaponry after all the silent darts, TRACER FIRE streakin them, but not aimed...both LIFTED, rising in the dark and WILDLY toward the ceiling, bullets clanging into the meta taking out bottles of juice on the belt, the muzzles spin effect almost like a child in the dark twirling two light BLONSKY: seeing the same. Despite bullets spraying everyw doesn't hesitate, HE CHARGES... bringing up his GUN, spri the moving machinery. He sees THE MUZZLE FLASHES STOP and THE SOUNDS OF BODIES HITTING THE GROUND. THE SHADOW MOVES AGAIN. BLONSKY: Drops to his knee with his partner beside him an OPEN FIRE ON THE SHADOW as it moves to the right across t field toward TEAM 3. If the Roars were loud before they now become truly horri THE THING in the DARK turns and moves from left to right, Soldiers' pan their fire concentrating it on the shadow, it clanking into machinery sparks flying, but...

dialogues.text: As the SHADOW moves across Team 1's fire toward Team 3, B BREAKS AND RUNS RIGHT. As always, one step ahead, moving position. He sees.. A LADDER UP TO A CATWALK RUNNING THE OF THE FACTORY. He goes for it. TEAM 3: The Monster coming past their position now, headi the EXIT in the far corner...they OPEN FIRE with BLONSKY' moving in behind them and shooting high over their heads. IMPOSSIBLE THAT THEY COULD BE MISSING IT. SOUND OF BULLETS CLANKING INTO METAL mixed with SOUND OF HITTING FLESH... a flat, thick sound.

dialogues.speaker: BULLETS
dialogues.text: BLONSKY: Reaches the cat walk and spins.. Can make out hi the dark... follow the line of their tracers into the sha . and then a ROAR and a SICKENING RENDING OF STEEL and AN TOWER of the CONVEYOR BELT is being torn from its base.. SWUNG at the SOLDIERS LIKE A CLUB. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  27. FROM BEHIND THE SOLDIERS: The CONVEYOR BELT coming at the giant clothesline of steel. They turn to run and dive but catches BOTH OF TEAM 3 in the back, SMASHING THEM TO THE BLONSKY'S PARTNER DIVES, but it tumbles onto his leg, BRE BONE. HE SCREAMS. VAN: All cameras dead. Monitors black. Just the sounds of moaning over the mic.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: Sir, no!!

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: THE SHAPE IS MOVING AGAIN NOW... Faster, it's tormentors it heads for the back corner, moving under the catwalk wh

BELOW, LOOKING BACK UP: The SHADOW is moving right at us, just a BLACK SHAPE. BLONSKY above and beyond IT on the left..OPENS FIRE. THE TRACERS STREAK IN STRAIGHT AT US, H THE FORM IN THE RIGHT SHOULDER BLADE. ENRAGED IT SPINS an does....

dialogues.text: ABOVE THE FACTORY FLOOR, spinning... But still able to wa THE HULK bends down into shadow..and with a mighty heave,

dialogues.speaker: OVER ROSS' SHOULDER, RUNNING TOWARD THE LOOMING WALLS OF
dialogues.text: FACTORY until...

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: INT. BANNER’S APARTMENT - LATER - DAWN ROSS is looking around for clues in Banner’s existence. C finishing a conversation with the BRAZILIAN OFFICER.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: The stuff in the bottles was basic lab chemicals. Zero intel. Like he knew we were coming and cleaned the place. Not a scrap of paper. As if on cue, BLONSKY enters... with BANNER’s BACKPACK. H it up on the table...

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Saw he had it on the run, but it was gone right before I got the shot off... found it under the machine that our guys got hit with. CABOT is already in it. Antenna...COMPUTER. Jackpot. And PICTURE OF BETTY. Blonsky examines it. BLONSKY (CONT’D) Girlfriend? Maybe she helps him... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  29. Cabot shoots a look at Ross. Hard, expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: No, we closed that door to him a long time ago. Ross takes the photo from Blonsky and stares at it for a beat. Thoughts unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Sir, with all respect...Does somebody want to tell me just what the hell went down in there? What was that thing? Ross looks away out the window at the light coming up on

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: There’s rumors in the street about sightings...farmer says he saw a gorilla going into the edge of the forest.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: That was no gorilla. It was 10 feet tall and green...or gray. I couldn’t tell. But it wasn’t an animal and you can’t tell me that thing is hiding somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Two thousand miles of jungle to hide in. He’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: What about Banner?

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: Local PD’s on alert. He must have got out when that Thing attacked us...

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: That was Banner.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: You think he led us into it?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: No I mean It...was Banner. It wasn’t an animal, it was him.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: You’re going to have to explain that statement.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: No, I’m not. You did your jobs well, both of you. We were undermanned and that’s my fault. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  30.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t think it would happen again... Pack up and get our men on the plane. We’re going home. He walks out leaving Cabot and Blonsky dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner wakes up in the woods. It's looks like the South A forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner makes his way up out of the trees to a rough mount A LOGGING TRUCK is coming down the road. He waves it down in the window

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Can you help me?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: No habla Portuguese.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Where..? Donde...donde estoy?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: Paroma. Paraguay? Brazil es ayi... Ochenta kilometers. He waves Banner inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner sits against a wall begging for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner buys clothes at a stall in the market. Finds stret pants finally. Better yet, finds a pair of Lycra shorts t like they'd almost be too big for him. Discreetly holds t of the Lycra shorts up behind a very fat lady and stretch leg hole wide - not as big as her back.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Mas grande. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A muddy alley full of raw trash. Banner is pulling on his clothes. Finishing he starts to ball up his shredded pant toss them in a pile when a piece of paper floats down out of the torn pockets. He throws the pants down and picks t up and looks at it... Data from MAYNARD He remembers what he needs to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two body bags in the back of the plane (Team 2). Two mobi hospital beds with commandos in them (Team 3). One soldie his leg up and splinted and his arm in a sling (Blonsky's partner). Only Blonsky made it through unhurt. He sleeps. Cabot is up front with Ross who is already studying Banne and correspondence with Mr. Blue. C.U. - COMPUTER SCREEN: we see Ross flicking past the evi Banner’s attempt to cure himself --

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: He’s tight, this one. No names, all authors names deleted. He was using a randomizer to tap different wireless networks every time he went online. We can’t even trace where his email went or where it came from. Ross absorbed in the pages, a new urgency breaking over h

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: He’s trying to get rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: We’ll have the Agency people down here keep their radar up.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter. He’s already on the move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner riding with migrant workers. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner hiking through rugged terrain to avoid border cros

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner trying to sleep in the doorway of a locked store i city somewhere. Car lights spill across him huddled there closed, but moving under the lids...

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: LIGHTS ACCELERATING AT US, horribly overcharged sound of HORN and a TREMENDOUS CRASH. Jump cutting -- The impossible image of the CAB OF A TRACTOR TRAILER bein over by our own massive hands... the HUGE LOAD OF LOGS ON SPILLING OUT BEYOND. All horribly distorted and streaked. Like an acid trip. BANNER WAKES: eyes darting. He shakes it off and gets up keeps moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night crossing the desert border with illegals (Mexico to family has children with them, having trouble. Banner pic up and helps the child across the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner jumps a FREIGHT TRAIN. In the U.S. now...heading somewhere. INT. GENERAL GRELLER’S OFFICE - DAY Greller sits at his desk looking up at Ross, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: GRELLER
dialogues.text: You wanna tell me that one more time?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Do I look like I’m not being serious, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: GRELLER
dialogues.text: T., I’ve known you a long time and I’ve never seen a cooler head under fire. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  33.

dialogues.speaker: GRELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know something bit you in the ass down there, but that is one hell of a White Whale story. And I am way out on a limb with you on this already.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Ask Blonsky. INT. GRELLER’S OFFICE - WAITING AREA - SAME BLONSKY sits in dress uniform, waiting. DOOR OPENS from t office. ROSS stands there...nods. INT. GRELLER’S OFFICE - SAME

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: -..yes, sir. I’d say ten or eleven feet. I’d put him at 1500 pounds easily but could be more. And green. Or gray. Greenish gray. It was very dark. I put three clips on it, sir and didn’t even flinch. I didn’t miss, I’1l stake my medals on that.

dialogues.speaker: GRELLER
dialogues.text: Captain, is there a medal you haven’t won?

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Medal of Honor, sir. A high percentage are given posthumously of course. Greller rubs his forehead, Blonsky still sharp at attenti

dialogues.speaker: GRELLER
dialogues.text: Relax, will you Blonsky? T., you wanna tell me what the hell you think is really going on here?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Banner’s work was a tangent of Bio-Tech.

dialogues.speaker: GRELLER
dialogues.text: You told me you were going to Brazil to nab a scientist. Are you telling me one of your Super Soldier experiments got out of the box?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I’m telling you that this could be an incredibly dangerous weapon in the wrong hands and we have no idea what his intentions are. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  34.

dialogues.speaker: GRELLER
dialogues.text: Put together a new list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross and Blonsky walk out of the meeting with Greller.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Are you telling me he becomes that thing at will?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I don’t have an answer to that, soldier.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Greller said “Super Soldier”. Do you mind if I ask...

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Yes, I mind. You’re asking questions way above your paygrade, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Respectfully sir, I lost two men back there who had made it through some bad shit with me. One was on his way out to have a family. I’d just like to know what we got mixed up in.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A classic silver-car diner near the base. Through the pla windows in a corner booth we see Ross and Blonsky over a

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: .-..do appreciate your professionalism but let me emphasize that what I’m about to share with you is tremendously sensitive to both me personally and the Army. Blonsky nods, all ears

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sure you’re aware that we’ve got an Infantry Weapons Development program...within it however we ran a subprogram for Bio-Tech Force Enhancement. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  35.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Super Soldier.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Yes...an oversimplification...but yes. Across the hall they’re trying to arm you better, we were trying to make you better. In all the obvious ways and some not so obvious. Banner’s work was very early phase, it wasn’t even a weapons application. It was radiation mitigation, see if we could give our boys built in insulation against all that depleted uranium nobody likes talking about. It was promising but politicians don’t give a Flying F about what real soldiers need, they like big twin rotor heli-planes that don’t work that they can build in their states... and so our money was running out. Banner was so sure of what he was on to that he tested it on himself. It was supposed to be very low-exposure and something went wrong. Or went very right... I still don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Why did he rabbit on you?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Banner was brilliant, one ina generation...but he is scientist, not one of us. He doesn’t grasp that to have peace and freedom you need Power. That people like you and I need instruments to do what we do.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: So it’d be good to nail him sure, but why not just take the data to someone else?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Because he IS the data. As far as I’m concerned, that man’s whole body is property of the US Army.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: I have real contempt for people like that.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You and me both, Captain. You and me both.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: What about the rest of it? You tried other things? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  36.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It was very promising but none of it panned out. Or, it did but it was...unstable. Made the subjects unstable. I wanted to refine it.. but then Al-Haquid happened and Congress killed it. No stomach.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: You’1l need something special to go against that thing. Someone who can survive to learn how to fight it. I’d be willing.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Blonsky, how old are you? 40?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Why are you still a Captain? You should be a full Colonel with your record. Shit you could be a Senator! Take your pick. Get out of the trench.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to lead. I’m a fighter. That’s all I want to be and I want to be the best for as long as I can and I don’t want to lose a step and if there’s something I can take to give me an edge, I want it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Well, I’m glad to see that all that advertising we do actually works. You know when I came back from Vietnam I was 27. I looked 45. So you're beating the curve. But it takes a toll doesn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Yes it does. They clink glasses. Mutual respect growing. A team formin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross admits himself and one medical technician into a sec medical storage room. It takes codes to get through doors Individual codes to open any of the cold storage lockers. opens one..the fog of liquid nitrogen keeping something p Ross nods and the technician lifts out the metal canister Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After hours and off the books. Ross supervises as Blonsky his first injection of the Super Soldier serum. TWO MEDIC make the preparations.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL TECH
dialogues.text: You’1l get two separate infusions, dripped in very slowly. One into the deep muscle, one into bone marrow centers. The bone ones are going to hurt.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: We’re giving you a very low dose only. I need you sharp out there, disciplined. First side of any side effect and we stop and you’re off team until you straighten out. Agreed? Blonsky nods again. He’s committed.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A sprawling semi-rural Southeastern campus. PANNING WITH TWO STUDENTS walking along a path the camera BANNER: standing by a tree, He scopes out the surroundings, not overly intense but ca He walks to a BIG STONE BUILDING. He looks up... MAYNARD HALL OF PHYSICAL SCIENCES (the note in his pocket He watches as students and faculty flow in and out. He mo steps and peers through the doors POV: a SECURITY PASS THROUGH. Guards checking ID’s, a met detector. More secure than in his day. He walks away, head down, thinking...passing ANOTHER BUIL stops. Looks at it. BIOLOGY. He hangs a moment, deciding then goes in the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANNER scans the directory/faculty board. Searching for something... and there it is... “CELLULAR BIOLOGY - DR. ELIZABETH ROSS” Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  38. He slips back out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner on a bench: Reading a book and watching the door. TWO WOMEN talking together as they exit, and one of them BETTY ROSS. Dark, lovely. He sits frozen: the closest he’s been to her in five year And then he follows-- Bruce watching Betty: keeping his distance - she gets coffee with the friend and sits and talks - says goodbye and checks her blackberry and smiles and t She is walking now...He could go to her...and then... ...-he sees the guy walking toward her smile. And she smi and accepts his embrace and kiss. This is SAMSON. They li and walk together and Banner has to watch them walk away, hand slipping inside Samson's. Another life. He turns away and puts himself back on cour

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner, STAN, early 60's, is turning the sign on the d CLOSED when a figure slides up and knocks on the glass. S freezes as he sees the face of... BANNER. Stan looks like he’s seen a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce and the owner catch up. Clearly, they were friends Bruce's old life.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: -..SO Many rumors. People say the worst things without any idea what they’re saying.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Stan, I promise you, whatever you’ve heard about me isn’t true. Stan pats his leg... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  39.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: I know it. I know people and I always knew it. But you know how I felt about you two... Have you talked to...?

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: No. She’s with....

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Samson. Yeah, you heard. He’s a head shrink. They say one of the best. But a good guy. Take my word. Reminds me of you a lit-- Sorry. Bruce, what can I do to help you?

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: I could use a place to stay a few nights.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: You'll stay in the spare room upstairs. Use the back, nobody’1l see you come or go.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Great. One other thing...can I deliver a few pizzas?

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Deliver all you want, I'll give Lou the week off. But someday you gotta tell me what all this was about.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER

dialogues.text: He’s synthesizing it but I had to try to get it at the source. It took a long time just to get there. And I couldn’t get a thousandth of what I’d need. If he’s even right...

dialogues.text: And now?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE

dialogues.text: No, you don’t. She gets up and goes to a bookshelf with a vase on it. Sh out a small DATA/FLASHCARD on ring, with a lanyard. She g and hands it to him.

Betty take hand until he pulls himself together.

dialogues.text: Whatever you may think, I didn’t come here to see Betty...

dialogues.speaker: SAMSON
dialogues.text: Then why did you come?

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: I have a problem...I thought part of the solution might be here.

dialogues.speaker: SAMSON
dialogues.text: Cryptic. But I’ll take it at face value. I’1l confess something to you if you’ll clear up some things for me...First, I confess, aS a man...as Betty’s lover... that I have always hoped you were dead. Not because I didn’t like you but because I love Betty and I’ve known that unless you were really gone, or she believed you were, that there would always be three of us in this relationship. I’ve dreaded the thought of you walking through the door. But now that you’re here...I have to admit that I’m very happy about it. Because I’m also a psychiatrist. And I’m very committed to putting light into dark corners, so to speak, and I’m very good at finding my way into the places people hide their secrets. I do it primarily because I think it helps them but also frankly because I’m interested in what people have to hide. Betty has a very dark corner that I have never found my way into, despite considerable, careful effort. And the only thing I know about her dark place is that you are in it. And I’m wondering if you’1ll be honest enough to tell me: why are you something that she won’t talk about? This is said simply, directly...without threat or malice.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: There are...aspects of my personality that I can’t control. And I hurt Betty...in ways I will never forgive myself for. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  53.

dialogues.speaker: SAMSON
dialogues.text: You don’t drop your career and fall off the face of the earth for five years because you’ve got an anger management issue, Bruce. You see a shrink.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: It’s a little more complicated than that. Samson, I’ve been alone for a long time now. I have to be. The toughest part of it is that I worry about what I’ve done to Betty. If she’s happy and you’re a part of that, then that makes me very happy. Honestly. The last thing I want to do is cause any trouble for her...or for you. I’d kill myself before I’d hurt her again.

dialogues.speaker: SAMSON
dialogues.text: Totally honest and yet avoiding something. Exactly like her. INT. SAMSON AND BETTY’S HOUSE - MORNING Bruce pulling his sweatshirt on, stepping into the hall. hear Betty and Samson in the kitchen. Talking in low tone barely hears....

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: What were we doing here? I mean what were we really trying to accomplish? Do you ever ask yourself that?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, you’ve turned this on yourself too hard. We did talk about it and we were all comfortable. The worst you can say is that you rushed it...but you took your own risks, you didn’t ask anybody else too.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: But it wasn’t me that died.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Nobody thought something like that was possible...

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: I don’t know...Nature took a long time to build us like we are...this whole delicate wonderfully sophisticated system refined over billions of years. We come in and monkey with it...think we can improve it overnight. Sooner or later it’s going to blow up in our face... Thunder rumbles in the distance.. a summer storm. As they are talking... he begins to perceive something od clearing away from the open campus... is it about to rain In the distance beyond a building: A STUDENT reacting to unseen BANNER’s eyes flick: Just beyond the far edge of a buildi A SNIPER MOVES FOR POSITION...THEY'VE COME FOR HIM. His f tenses... He grabs Betty

dialogues.speaker: BANNER, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: BANNER

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What’s the FBI gonna do...pull out badges? Why don’t we get ATF while we’re at it!

dialogues.speaker: GRELLER
dialogues.text: It's formalities, T. Use em for intel and then tell em to back off. The Chiefs are giving you total authority to run this operation. Make your list of what you need and get back to me. Ross hangs up. Looks up at the news in time to catch: TV NEWS: REPORTER standing with TWO COLLEGE KIDS, slacker clearly stoned.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Very few outside the military got a first- hand look at their rumored adversary. Sophomores Jack McGhee and Kevin Feige were coming home from a hike and witnessed some of the battle. McGhee captured this on his cell phone

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMELY GRAINY IMAGE OF HULK BATTLING SEEN FROM FAR AWA
dialogues.text: REPORTER (CONT’D) Can you describe what you saw?

dialogues.speaker: MCGHEE
dialogues.text: Dude, it was like a huge and green... HUGE... I mean like the way Steve Nash looks standing next to Shaq...Shaq would look like that standing next to this...

dialogues.speaker: FEIGE
dialogues.text: Dude, it was so big. It was like this huge....Hulk Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  76.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Further search for the mysterious ‘Hulk’ was delayed by powerful thunderstorms in the Smoky Mountain National forest. ROSS breaks away as CABOT enters breathless:

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: It’s Blonsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cabot and Ross hustle down the hall, Ross grim faced. As through the ICU door

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Has anybody found out if he has next of kin or family?

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: You can ask him yourself. BLONSKY’s BED: Doctors and nurses standing around the end part to reveal: BLONSKY: sitting up on the end of the bed in his underwea talking and laughing with doctors. HE IS COMPLETELY HEALE More than healed, HE LOOKS STRONGER THAN EVER, literally. SUPER-SOLDIER SERUM IS TURNING HIM INTO AN ADONIS. Blonsky is grinning like a cat. Astounded Ross shakes his

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Good to see you on your feet, Soldier. How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Pissed off and ready for Round 3. INT. MOTEL ROOM —- MORNING ON THE BED: Phone; credit card; bank card; license; $70 c up; University ID, small camera. BANNER: all but the cash, camera goes back in the purse.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Can’t use any of it but the cash. Don’t even turn the phone on, they can track it. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  77.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: My lipstick? Can they track that?

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: No you can keep that.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Not going to get where we’re going on 70 bucks.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Not quickly enough. Betty turns and reaches for a small chain around her thro up A GOLD PENDANT. Takes it off.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. It’s the only thing of hers that you have. No.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: We'll get it back. INT. ARMY BASE —- PLANNING ROOM - DAY Ross has a real team assembled now. Technicians, intel, l enforcement. All of it. There are at least two dozen peop the room and Cabot is wrapping up the briefing. Ross stan the side. BANNER and BETTY’S PHOTOS FILLS THE SCREEN

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: ...Federal is already monitoring phone, plastic and Dr. Ross’s web accounts, and local PD's have been put on alert... They’1l pop up somewhere and when they do it comes straight to us...

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: They won’t just pop up. He made it five years and got across borders without making a mistake and he won’t use a damn credit card now. If he was trying to escape he’d be long gone. But he’s not trying to escape...he’s looking for help. And that’s how we’re going to get him. We don’t know where they’re going but we know what they’re after and we know he’s been talking to somebody. You've all got copies of that correspondence. There are only a few hundred people in world who have what he needs. Figure out who they are, he’s going to one of them. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  78.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: Under no circumstances whatsoever are your people to engage these subjects directly. Apprehension will be handled exclusively from this office. Call it in and we'll tell you what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty exiting with cash. She pawned her mother’s locket.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: We'll get it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce and Betty with a “FOR SALE” sign in their hands, bu something in cash from the YOUNG GUY behind the counter. is on a computer. Banner offers the guy $50.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Mind if I send a quick email off your account? Guy takes the money happily and Banner quickly plugs in t card and sends a message to Mr. Blue/Sterns. SCREEN/EMAIL: “What you requested is attached. Maybe it’s meet. Green.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Bruce getting into their newly purchased BATTER PICKUP TRUCK. Bruce getting in the passenger side...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Hey... He turns and she has her little camera out. He gives her quizzical look.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s been worse than this before right?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Yes...much worse.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Then we’re on the way to something better. He smiles a sad uncertain smile and she SNAPS THE PICTURE Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty drives. Banner stares out in to the dark, a darker back on him.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Penny for your thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: How long have you known Samson?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: About a year and a half. He came to lecture on a fellowship and stayed.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Do you trust him?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yes. I do. Bruce, you know that I...

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: You don’t have to explain anything to me. Ever. He seems like a good man and he treats you well and that makes me happy.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: He does. I never trusted him with this. Trust isn’t the right word. I didn’t test his faith in me by asking him to believe something I still can’t believe myself.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Who could? Sometimes I even convince myself it’s not real.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: What is it like...when it happens? What do you experience?

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Remember those clinical experiments we volunteered for at Harvard? The induced hallucinations? It’s like that, amplified by a thousand. It feels like someone is pouring a liter of acid into my brain. The sound is the worst.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Do you remember anything?

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Fragments. Nothing I can derive anything from. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  80.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: But then it’s still you...inside it.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: It’s not me.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: In the cave, I felt that you knew...that IT knew me. Maybe your mind is in there it’s just...overcharged...can’t process what’s happening. You know Samson works with people on ‘conscious dreaming’, helping them direct themselves out of their nightmares even though the conscious brain seems asleep... maybe...

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: I don’t want to control it. I want to get rid of it. It kills people. It almost killed you. I didn’t do those things.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Of course not... He looks out the window in silence, tormented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blonsky sits on the table. TWO MEDICAL TECHS are prepping syringes that we saw deliver Blonsky his first dose of Su Soldier serum. He’s getting more. Reveal ROSS: standing there. He’s authorized it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Let’s even the game a little. DREAM IMAGE: A rough wooden door opening from the inside bright sunlight washing in to reveal HIGH PEAKS of the HIMALAYAS; a rocky path leading up to u it a MONK in saffron and red robes. He looks up at us and holds up a hand in greeting and SMI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANNER WAKES UP: disoriented. THE RADIO is on news... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  81.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I thought I should let you sleep.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Stuck in traffic. But getting close. He looks around. Traffic lockup. Radio talking about traf delays due to heightened security alert. He opens the doo stands up to look. POV: the gates of a toll booth a long way ahead (maybe we it says “Holland Tunnel”. He can see uniformed officers a standing by toll gates looking at faces.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Go where?

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: We've got to get out.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Right here...I mean...now?

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Yes, right here....let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: doors of the truck open and two figures slide out...pick through honking cars and disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner and Betty walk down the sidewalk and we pan and se they are heading for the WATER’S EDGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANNER and BETTY talking to an OLDER GUY standing by a ra fishing pole and bucket (Stan Lee!). They’re offering him money and he’s nodding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce and Betty in the bow of a small OUTBOARD MOTOR BOAT OLDER GUY throttles up and as they move out into the rive UP to reveal: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  82. NEW YORK CITY: and this is where they’re heading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Bruce on the sidewalk by a kiosk with a map

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Long way uptown. Subway’s quickest.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Me in a tight metal tube underground with hundreds of other people in the most aggressive city in the world?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Right. Let’s get a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCREAMING up 6th Avenue. The DRIVER is without a doubt th terrifying cab driver in a whole city of bad cab drivers. Slashing across two lanes, accelerating like an F-1 racer and honking nearly killing a bike messenger, racing throu lights from much too far away. All with RADIO BLARING and PHONE talking a mile a minute. Banner and Betty getting tossed around like dolls.

dialogues.speaker: PULSE MONITOR
dialogues.text: Banner: head back eyes closed, breathing deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAM! Betty and Banner have bailed on Hell Ride. Betty hurling money in increments through the passenger w

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: --.god forbid you should give a SHIT about the living, breathing PEOPLE in the back of your office on wheels with no SHOCKS...

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: What’s the matter baby? You no like a good ride? He makes a kiss noise and takes off. Betty BOOTS the rear he goes Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  83.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Asshole!!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You know I can show you some techniques to help you manage that rage a little better...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Zip it. We're walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner and Betty walk up along the Park past the Natural Museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banner and Betty enter the gates of COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CABOT in a glassed-in office off the OPEN ROOM full of de terminals. AN INTELLIGENCE OFFICER walks in with a file

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: That’s from Quantico. They’re getting blanked. The academic language in the published stuff could be three dozen off our list. And we haven’t even got samples for three dozen more. CABOT sighs... She nods and the OFFICER goes out. She rub temples and stares at her COMPUTER. Gets a ‘what the fuck her face and types: SCREEN: Google Search: “Mr Blue cellular biology” A bunch of links come up and she clicks one and gets: A YOU TUBE VIDEO: Scientist JR STERNS holds a press confe demonstrate a breakthrough for medical science.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: “,..full cell saturation, a method of moving desired compounds into every cell in the body which will revolutionize medical therapies.” VIDEO: Sterns puts an inert blue dye into a WILD LOOKING hooked up to a YOUNG GRADUATE STUDENT. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  84. In front of our eyes, the student starts to TURN BLUE. PE laugh and clap at the demonstration.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s his name?

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: Who, Mr. Blue here? CABOT: BOLTS FORWARD, EYES WIDE. Her fingers fly across t keyboard, typing in the name “JR STERNS cellular biology” A Google link appears for Columbia University. Cabot clic link and uploads a photo of Professor JR Sterns, the same the You Tube video.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: They’re going to New York!!

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY SCIENCE BUILDING LOBBY
dialogues.text: Professor Sterns emerges.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Dr Sterns?

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Sorry to bother you. I’m Elizabeth Ross.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: Dr. Ross, my goodness...I read your wonderful paper on synthesizing nucleotides!! To what do I owe the...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: There’s someone I’d like to introduce you to...

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Mr. Blue, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: Mr Green! INT. STERNS’ LAB - DAY - SOME TIME LATER The lab has a bit of the ‘Mad Scientist’ clutter to it. S speaks very quickly. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  85.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: +..it took some work, let me tell you, we’ve never tried to concentrate the trimethodine a tenth of what your peak exposure correlates with. That you survived an event like that to stand here and discuss this....it has something to do with Dr. Ross’s protein primer capacitating the cells of course, but it’s beyond my reckoning...we could study it for years.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: But you think you’ve got the concentration right?

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: Well yes...on paper anyway. And my cell saturation will make sure we don’t miss any spots...but...even if we hit the levels right, I can’t promise this will cure you. It might only be an antidote to suppress the specific flare up. When you have one of these ‘spikes’ ... is the experience extreme?

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: You might say that.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: Well I can’t wait to see it! You know I must say...I wondered if you were real. And if you were I wondered what it would look like...a person with that much power lurking in him. Nothing could have surprised me more than this unassuming young man shaking my hand! (hesitates) I'd be remiss however if I didn’t point out that these concentrations carry extraordinary levels of toxicity. If we're over by even a small integer, the residual could kill you. Will kill you.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: There’s a flip side to that ... if we miss on the low side...if we induce me and it fails...it will be very dangerous for you.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: I’ve always been more curious than cautious. It’s served me well so far but if that’s what kills this cat in the end...well at least I’‘1ll have peeked around a few corners. (smiles) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  86.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So then we’re all agreed? (they nod) Into the Glorious Unknown!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross’ forces mobilize. A Sikorsky winding up its jets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blonsky stands alone, staring at himself in the mirror, s his own face. Something is changing in him. HIS SHOULDERS NECK SEEM TO HAVE GROWN MASSIVE LITERALLY OVERNIGHT. As he studies his body and face, we pull round to his ref back over his shoulder, further back revealing his naked we can see something that even he can’t...

dialogues.speaker: .--SOMETHING VERY STRANGE IS HAPPENING TO THE BONES IN HI
dialogues.text: They have become too big, almost simian, protruding from his enlarged back muscles in a disturbing way.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. SIKORSKY
dialogues.text: Blonsky loads in with OTHER SPECIAL FORCES SOLDIERS. Ther

dialogues.speaker: AGAINST ONE WALL.
dialogues.text: BLONSKY sits against the wall next to a familiar face, a who was in the campus fight with him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: How you feeling, man?

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Like a monster. Blonsky grunts aggressively and flexes his arm. HIS ARM M ACTUALLY TEARS HIS SLEEVE A LITTLE. The other soldier sho look around. Cabot and Ross come back to the rear to brief the team. S copies of BLUEPRINTS OF THE LAYOUT OF STERNS BUILDING AND

dialogues.speaker: SURROUNDING BUILDINGS
dialogues.text: BLONSKY (CONT’D) Back on the Hulk Hunt, Major...

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: Banner is the target. Snipers have the point. Delta in backup. If we make it before they move we’ll have two tries. If we can’t take him inside, we'll try for a shot as he exits. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  87.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we can’t hit him unaware before he makes the street then plainclothes will try to follow and we stand down. Under no circumstance is Banner to be engaged directly. If we can’t get a shot we fall back and let him go.

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: And if he goes nuclear?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Then we’ll have failed to learn from our mistakes, won’t we? You’ve got the compact sonics. Try to at least move him out of the city center toward the river. Then disengage. We’1ll follow from the air but not fight. Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: BLONSKY
dialogues.text: Not much of a rematch.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: 1.5 Million people within a five mile radius. You want to fight that thing here? Cabot steps to the front of the cabin, sits near Ross.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You sure about your boy?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I need a dog in the hunt that’s not going to run from a bear if it shows up. If we do this right, I’1l never have to let him off the leash. INT. STERNS’ LAB - EVENING Sterns and Betty make the preparations to ‘treat’ Banner. a table that looks disturbingly like a set-up for a letha injection. A little bit of a Frankenstein vibe too. Banner strips to his lycra shorts and gives his clothes t

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Think of all the money I’1l save on wardrobe if this works. If this starts to go bad, promise me you won’t stay and try to help me.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Bruce... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  88.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: It’s the worst when it starts. You have to promise me you’ll run or I can’t do this. Betty nods. Sterns indicates the nylon medical restraints

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: If you have a strong reaction these will keep you from hurting yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: If I have a strong reaction you’re not going to need to worry about me. Banner climbs on the table. Sterns tilts it back so that still at a slight angle and begins to strap him in. Sterns puts an I.V. in each of Banner’s arms and legs lin the CELL SATURATION MACHINE which he primes. A canister w antidote and some sort of futuristic spinner or plunger t through his body. Then he puts contact pads connected to electrical wires on Banner’s temples. And finally a plast suppressor for Banner’s mouth. Banner shakes it off.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: Ready? STERNS JOLTS BANNER WITH ELECTRICITY. A lot of it. It hit HIS WHOLE BODY SPASMS, every muscle in his body straining the straps, eyes clenched and then - CLOSE ON BANNER’S EYES: snapping open, GREEN LIGHT glowin A PULSE OF GREEN in the base of his skull sends green Gam shooting through his body, HIS SKIN FLOODS WITH COLOR FRO

dialogues.speaker: STERNS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My God...!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: There’s more. Wait for it! Now we see the full agony of it as Banner’s body starts t and stretch and harden. We should feel the trauma of it o bones and muscles. Sterns is staggered. Betty watches the loves be tortured in front of her, he howls in agony. Ste closer...too close. The restraints pop like rubber bands, one of them strikin who gets knocked back and dazed...The Hulk is appearing o table, still in spasms. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  89.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now! Do it! The table starts to buckle under the weight as THE HULK c to grow. Hulk is going to lift his head up and get seriou any second... but then BETTY LITERALLY JUMPS ONTO THE TABLE OVER HIM, leaning on massive torso, looking for his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, STAY WITH ME
dialogues.text: Banner/Hulk howls.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do it NOW!!!! Sterns hits the button and THE ANTIDOTE starts to flow in And slowly, painfully, THE PROCESS STARTS TO REVERSE. You almost see the fluid moving through those massive veins a finding its way into every corner and calm the radiation his blood. AND HE SHRINKS... Finally, Banner is back, lying on the buckled table with kneeling over him. She strokes his forehead. He’s drenche sweat, wrung out like a marathoner.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s alright. You’re alright. It’s over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helicopters landing. Snipers and Blonsky’s team hit the g running. CABOT AND ROSS moving with MOBILE COMMUNICATIONS right behind. All heading into waiting UNMARKED VANS on 1 INT. STERNS’ LAB - NIGHT They’re debriefing. Sterns talks a mile a minute.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: ---the pulse came from the amygdala. I think Dr. Ross’ ‘primer’ lets the cells absorb the energy temporarily and then it abates. That’s why you didn’t die of radiation sickness years ago. Now maybe we've neutralized those cells permanently or maybe we just suppressed that event. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  90.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m inclined to think the latter because none of our test subjects had a decline in absorption capacity, but of course they were getting Gamma in MUCH lower doses externally each time... But You! It’s like you’ve got a turbo booster in your brain. It’s one of the most wonderful things I’ve ever seen!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It’s not wonderful for Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: In a medical science sense, of course. You're miraculous.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: So how did you know it would work?

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: I didn’t. But now that we have the data on Bruce’s initial -

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Wait. You said ‘test subjects’. What test subjects? Sterns gestures and they follow him to a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sniper teams take roof positions around Sterns lab buildi team with one shooter and one spotter with a THERMAL SCAN SCANNERS springing on line. A THERMAL IMAGE of Betty, Ban Sterns moving from one part of the lab into another.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: Target is the tallest, in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night. No civilians. AN NYPD SWAT OFFICER is hustling a S GUARD OUT OF THE LOBBY. Blonsky and his team move into po in LOBBY. BLONSKY near the stairwell. INT. STERNS’ LAB / INT. LOBBY / INT. COMMAND POST IN ANOT

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING LOBBY / EXT. ROOFTOP
dialogues.text: STERNS’ LAB - THE OTHER ROOM: MUTATED ANIMALS: Rats, rhee monkeys - some normal, others slightly Hulked-out version themselves...none Green, they are more grey. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  gl.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: Oh my god... what have you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: Well you didn’t send me much of yourself to work with and I couldn’t risk blowing the opportunity so we concentrated it and grew more. The same thing you were trying to do with the corablanca! You were my flower, see? Banner is looking around in horror: his worst nightmare i true before his eyes. He has been replicated.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A lot of the first pass didn’t survive of course but as you can see we’re doing much better. And we’re only giving them very low-dose Gamma so no power-lifters yet but the interesting thing...

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: You've got to destroy all of it.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: Sorry, what...

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: All of it. Right now. Show me your supply.

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: You must be joking. We’ll share a Nobel for this, the three of us! Think of the applications.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter if it can’t be controlled...You don’t know the power of what we’re dealing with here!

dialogues.speaker: STERNS
dialogues.text: But we’ve got the antidote now! THERMAL IMAGE: of the three as seen by snipers. Banner mo a window zone, but Betty blocks a clean shot. CABOT: sits in front of a panel of video monitors, observ soldier camera feeds. Ross stands behind her.

dialogues.speaker: CABOT
dialogues.text: At your discretion shooter. SNIPER: eye to his scope... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  92.
